content:
Are you actually sure you are dealing with Thunderbird junk filtering. Your assumptions in your initial posting make me think you are not.

I strongly suggest you tread the user support document on junk filtering where you will become familiar with whitelisting. ie those in the address book do not become junk regardless of message content.

You would also become aware that the filtering has no regard to the from address except for the whitelisting function, so if every new address is being marked as spam, another source is highly likely as it is most unlikely that the spam filter can ever get so badly skewed that the content of every message becomes spam unless you had spent a long time trying to convince it that all text was spam.

So what antivirus product do you use? There are still some, I understand, that force scam and spam modules into Thunderbird, they don't even have setting in Thunderbird for these modules, just on off switches in the antivirus tool.

You might also want to consider what spam filtering your mail provider is applying. I am not aware of much specifically, but I understand there are options in say Yahoo to mark all new mail that is not in the Yahoo address book as spam.

I think in this instance that the source of the problem will not be Thunderbird, it might be, but my money os on an onside influence.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I read the user support document you linked -- not every word, but enough to determine that it doesn't solve the problem.

It has a note that says, "You should frequently... check your Junk folder for good messages wrongly marked as Junk." No; if I have to look at every message that the filter thinks is junk, the filter does nothing useful, and I might as well turn it off.

Whitelisting is not an effective filtering strategy. I need to be able to blacklist senders by clicking a message's Junk button or something like it. Thunderbird does not appear to have a blacklist. The term does not appear in the document you linked.

I see one possible solution: if clicking the Junk button actually adds the sender to a blacklist, and if adaptive junk filtering is the only actor that classifies messages as junk if they're not in the blacklist, turning off adaptive message filtering will make the system usable. I haven't tried that because I can't figure out exactly what clicking Junk does, or how adaptive filtering works. The document you linked does not explain those things. If that's not a solution I need a different one, and I hope you can help me find it.
creator: jsachs.sac

content:
It would help if we knew what you have currently got set up in the Account Settings > Junk Settings

Please post an image.

If you have Address Books with contacts then you may want all those contacts to be set up as a whitelist and not get classed as junk in the first place. In Junk Settings you need to select those address books. This helps to train the adaptive junk filter, so less of your emails get marked as junk.

Are you using a Pop or IMAP mail account ? If IMAP, then the server maybe setting some emails as junk/spam.

re : I can't figure out exactly what clicking Junk does

If you have adaptive junk filtering enabled which I would recommend, then the adaptive junk filter learns what you are selecting as Junk and it gets put into the training data. It also learns what you select as 'not junk'. After a period of time it will recognise the junk, mark as junk and auto put the junk email into the Junk or Spam folder in the account using the 'Junk Settings' criteria.

So in effect clicking on 'Junk' will build up a blacklist which the training data uses so it can get to recognise what you deem as junk.

Click on Junk will also move that email into a 'Junk' or 'Spam' folder depending upon settings.

Junk Settings (normal settings to use)

  • Select 'Move new junk messages to'
  • If Pop select 'Junk folder on and choose the account
  • If Imap choose 'Other' and select eg: 'Spam on account name'

DEfault Junk Settings are located here:

  • Settings > Privacy & SEcurity
  • Scroll to 'Junk'
  • Select 'When messages are marked as Junk
  • Select 'Move them to the accountss 'Junk Folder'
  • Select 'Enable adaptive junk filter logging'

Please note: if this is an IMAP account then the server will have it's own spam filter and it can mark something as Junk. Server auto puts those emails into the server Spam folder. You can tell if server marked as spam because the flame junk icon will be greyed out. If the junk flame icon is orange/red colour then it got marked as junk by Thunderbird adaptive filter or by you manually.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Jonathan Sachs said
I read the user support document you linked -- not every word, but enough to determine that it doesn't solve the problem.

You were starting from a position of ignorance and making assumptions, based on what I just read you are still making assumption and complaining that your assumptions are not documented (the existence of a blacklist). Hopefully you have no tread enough to know that nothing in Thunderbird has regard to the senders address in filtering junk. Something you made quite a bit about in your initial posting..

You should have also come away with the knowledge that Thunderbird is only one leg of a three legged stool when it comes to junk filtering and personally I doubt your issue has anything to do with Thunderbird.

It has a note that says, "You should frequently... check your Junk folder for good messages wrongly marked as Junk." No;

That is generic good advice for everyone at all times with any mail client or webmail. Checking the junk filter for incorrectly filtered mail is something everyone should be doing frequently. Especially with providers like Yahoo and Google that auto delete junk after a week or two. Don't do it and they will not only misclassify your mail, but will delete it as well.

if I have to look at every message that the filter thinks is junk, the filter does nothing useful, and I might as well turn it off.

I strongly encourage you to do exactly that. Right now

Then if the issue stops we will know the issue is in Thunderbird junk filter and if it does not stop the issue lies elsewhere.

Whitelisting is not an effective filtering strategy. I need to be able to blacklist senders by clicking a message's Junk button or something like it. Thunderbird does not appear to have a blacklist. The term does not appear in the document you linked.

There is no blacklist. You did not see one listed because it does not exist. Perhaps apply the information under the heading "Other ways of blocking unwanted messages" to obtain your aims.

Perhaps consult with your elected representatives if you have issues with persistent junk. I do not have issues in my jurisdiction, getting perhaps 10 unwanted unsolicited commercial email a week. Other countries with poorer regulation / laws with regard to unsolicited email apparently have more issues. I regularly see folk in this forum from the USA complaining about hundreds of such things each day, I can only put the difference down to the legislative branch of government as it is not my experience.

I see one possible solution: if clicking the Junk button actually adds the sender to a blacklist,

As the support document says "Thunderbird's adaptive junk filter is not an absolute barrier against messages from a specific address or specific types of messages. "

and if adaptive junk filtering is the only actor that classifies messages as junk if they're not in the blacklist,

and we do not know that do we!

turning off adaptive message filtering will make the system usable.

I suggest you turn of junk filtering, I doubt it is going to stop the misclassification unless you have poisoned the learning database with garbage by classifying mail based on sender. Nothing will confuse a tool that uses the content of a message to determine is is is spam than having every bit of text manually classified as spam.

Perhaps you should delete the files

I haven't tried that because I can't figure out exactly what clicking Junk does, or how adaptive filtering works. The document you linked does not explain those things. If that's not a solution I need a different one, and I hope you can help me find it.

The article I linked to states "Thunderbird's adaptive filter uses a Bayes algorithm plus training data you have collected to determine which messages it will automatically set as junk" Wikipedia can add to how that works as Bayesian algebra and it's application to spam scoring. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naive_Bayes_classifier#Spam_filtering It is a mathematical process which I do not pretend to understand.

The source code for Thunderbird junk filter is here, if Wikipedia's generic explanation of Bayesian filtering does not satisfy your quest for knowledge on exactly how the thing works. https://searchfox.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/extensions/bayesian-spam-filter/nsBayesianFilter.cpp

From a practical perspective all I know is the email is scored out of 100 as to the likelihood of it being junk and email that scores over 90 gets classified as spam. (Customizable via the config editor with hidden preference mail.adaptivefilters.junk_threshold ) But changing that is not going to do anything with your issue except probably make things worse.

As I said turn off the junk filtering, it does not do any blacklisting at all. It never has and probably never will as, that is contrary to the whole concept of analyzing the message content. That is why the article you claim to have read suggests the use of manual filters to build a blacklist. I wrote the initial draft of the manual filtering article, but to be brutally honest I wrote it to shut people up, not because I think it does anything long term. Manual junk filtering is a self defeating process. v where you will be busy blocking the address used yesterday while the spammer as moved on to two or three new ones in the interim.

Perhaps the best thing to do is delete the training.dat file from your Thunderbird profile folder (close Thunderbird before attempting to do that) and start the training all over again in the awareness that there is no blacklist and the origin of the email is entirely irrelevant to the analysis. So clicking junk on mail based on origin is almost guaranteed to reduce the effectiveness of the analysis as it is the content of the email that is used to build the database, not the sender or sender domain.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
If (almost) everything is marked as junk on a fresh Thunderbird Profile, your training data may be faulty or the server marks mail as junk independently of Thunderbird?

If you want to build a blacklist you might be able to do it using quickFilters - it has the ability to merge (read: extend) existing filters based on user actions such as moving to folders or adding tags. Maybe open an issue for a feature request or question on the quickFilters Github to discus a quick workflow:

https://github.com/RealRaven2000/quickFilters/issues

Underlying idea of quickFilters:

  • The user can activate a filter assistant mode, in which quickFilters monitors all file operations and tags instigated by the user.
  • Then quickFilters helps building a filter that replicates the user’s action, (which often involves moving a file deep in the folder hierarchy and may be cumbersome to create manually) to automate it.
  • if a filter already exists (in the mail account) that does this action (move to folders X) it will suggest merging the rule into it rather than creating a new filter. So you could have a filter called blacklist senders that marks junk as based on sender - maybe also tags it with a special tag you know it wasn’t done by Thunderbird’s adaptive junk control - that you can extend through the assistant.

Currently quickFilters implements a folder listener and a tag listener, which monitor changes. I am not sure whether it also is triggered by just marking as junk or whether you would have to move the mail to junk to trigger the assistant.

content: That window is the start of the OAuth2 authentication process. When your email address isn't automatically entered, it means you don't have cookies accepted in TB Settings/Privacy & Security. Accept cookies in Settings, then restart TB, where you should see your email in the window, and proceed to the next step where you enter the account (not app) password to allow access by TB.

content:
To set a background image for the message pane when no message is selected, add this to userChrome.css: 

#messagePane { background-image: url("file:///C:/Users/username/folder/imagename.jpg") !important;}


To set a background image for the message pane when a message is opened (and also the Settings tab), there is similar code for userContent.css:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1441091#answer-1639485
creator: sfhowes

content:
Review the steps carefully. An important step that is often forgotten is to ensure thunderbird is not running;

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
Hello, Your steps are what I did.

I tried several things (each time after uninstalling and re-installing Thunderbird, and 1st launch of Thunderbird):

- Overwrite new %APPDATA%/Roaming/Thunderbird folder with old content - Clear new %APPDATA%/Roaming/Thunderbird folder then paste old content - Use Thunderbird 32 bits ESR (the same version as in the old system) - Use Thunderbird 64 bits release - Also paste/replace %APPDATA%/Local/Thunderbird folder

And each time, accounts are created correctly, but some without the internal folders.

But two accounts are correctly ported. So the procedure must be correct.

What could cause some accounts to be incorrectly ported (without folders)?

"Local folders" entry, which is not an account , also lacks folders.

content: All I can figure is that thunderbird was running when copy was made. You can review this after making the copy, but viewing with windows file explorer. open the profile and look at the imapmail\<account> folder and the Mail\Local Folders folder to see contents. You can ignore the appdata\local step. If there is more than one profile in the profiles folder, the profiles.ini text file has the name of the one being used. If problems continue, it may help to post screenshot of the profile's imapmail folder, the Mail folder (if POP) and the Mail\Local Folders folder

content:
OK, so pop.free.fr is showing no messages? On the old pc, do you see messages in the inbox for pop.free.fr? Be sure to verify for which account that entry is for. You can do that at account settings and then server settings on bottom row. Also, just to review, you apparently did not do the steps I recommended, instead doing these:

- Overwrite new %APPDATA%/Roaming/Thunderbird folder with old content - Clear new %APPDATA%/Roaming/Thunderbird folder then paste old content - Use Thunderbird 32 bits ESR (the same version as in the old system) - Use Thunderbird 64 bits release - Also paste/replace %APPDATA%/Local/Thunderbird folder

My recommended approach was just this: - Overwrite new %APPDATA%/Roaming/Thunderbird folder with old content

I cannot see exactly what has transpired, so offer this potential rescue step: - install the addon, importexporttools, on both PCs - on old pc, highlight one of the folders that did not transfer properly to new oc - rightclick, and select the importexport option to export all messages in folder>EML message format>messages and HTML index - 0n new pc, highlight the desired folder that shows nothing and select the importexport option to import EML messages - repeat for each desired folder.
creator: davidsk

content:
Hello,

The problem is solved. The Roaming/Thunderbird folder copy created the accounts correctly.

But the local account files weren't in the standard location (Roaming on system drive): these huge files had been redirected to another drive with a backup.

So the method described works perfectly, and once the links to the local folders are corrected in the settings window, everything works.

Thank you very much.
creator: chebrou

content:
Remove your non windows defender antivirus and try again.

I used to tell people to disable antivirus, but some of the products are worse that the malware when it comes to actually disabling themselves. They say they do it and don't.

You can also use the operating system in safe mode with networking to remove antivirus and a loads of other startup problem makers like ccleaner, but most folks these days have a bargain basement WiFi connection to the internet that simply does not work in Windows safe mode. Only wired internet works with windows safe mode.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: wzydhek

content:
Run through a few checks...

1. Check Firewall Exit Thunderbird Access Firewall Thunderbird program must be set up as an allowed program.

2. Check for a VPN Please check to see if you have a VPN enabled. Servers do not like VPN and may block access to server.

3. Check - localhost If you have anything using localhost such as Apache Xampp (people use it when managing websites) then you must switch it off until oauth is set up.

4. 2FA and app generated password In gmail - Switch off 2FA and do not use an app specific password you may have generated. The password when requested is the normal one you use to access webmail.

5. Check cookies are enabled You must have the following : Thunderbird

  • Settings > Privacy & Security

Web Content

  • Select 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • Accept third party cookies 'Always
  • click on 'Exceptions'
  • Add this as an 'allowed' exception : https://accounts.google.com
  • click on 'Save Changes'

Whilst in that area make sure to delete any passwords that have been previously saved for that gmail account. You do not want any to get used whilst setting up account. Otherwise gmail may expect eg: an oauth password so will reject the normal password when setting up account OR if an app generated password has been saved, it will also confuse gmail - so check - remove all saved passwords for that gmail account.

  • Scroll down to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Click on 'Show Passwords'

If you get a 'Windows Security' window asking for password - enter the same password you enter when you start computer and logon to User Account to see desktop etc. It's not talking about a mail account password.

  • Completely remove any password to do with that gmail account - imap:// or smtp:// or oauth://
  • click on 'Close'

Then restart Thunderbird. Create a new mail account.

  • New > Existing mail account
  • Enter name, email address and normal password (same password you use to access gmail webmail account)
  • Click on Continue

Server settings should be auto located - imap will get chosen by default and set up to use OAuth2.

When you click on Done You should be prompted by gmail to allow Thunderbird access which you need to complete.

Please report back on results.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: I am a Linux user, but the results may translate to Windows as well. I tried for the last 3 days to add on 2 new accounts with no success. The resolution that I found that worked was to go into Settings > Privacy and click to allow Cookies from websites. Save that and go back to the main screen. Setup the account using the New Account setup. I am using IMAP on the default server. Prior to that, every attempt would give me a failed to connect to server message. Once the account is setup, you can shut off Cookies again with no other issues. Again, I am using the Linux version: EndeavourOS Linux x86_64 using Kernel version 6.12.17-1-lts.
creator: scarecrow333

content: as I mentioned, cookies are enabled.

content: Glad you were able to get it connected. I looked up other's that have issues getting the authentication, and it looks like there can be issues with the OAuth in advanced settings being setup wrong initially, not a user fault. So it may not be pulling in the right setup for POP3 or IMAP for you in auto setup. I saw where someone had to change it so that incoming was set to OAuth and outgoing is set to OAuth2. You might try going into advanced setup, and manually have it map the connection. There is a button that will let you map the server connection. With cookies on, it should in theory give you the Google account authentication screen on your PC. If you have a firewall running, it may be blocking the port needed for that connection. I would also click cookies on and off, just to make sure it recognizing the option. Best of luck!
creator: scarecrow333
